title: Survey: Why did you join League?
body: Pretty straight forward I'd say. I'm trying to collect data on this, so think back to your first days of League. What exactly made you look at this game and go "..Why not?"

replies.body:
I wanted to indulge my inner megalomaniac. {{champion:45}} gave me that opportunity and I never looked back.

I also enjoyed the variety of characters and their respective designs; transhumanist cyborgs ({{champion:112}}), ninjas ({{champion:84}} {{champion:98}} {{champion:238}} {{champion:85}}), freaky aliens ({{champion:121}} {{champion:161}} {{champion:96}} {{champion:421}} {{champion:31}}), classical fairytale magic ({{champion:45}} {{champion:117}} {{champion:1}}  {{champion:57}} {{champion:267}} {{champion:102}}), ancient Egyptians ({{champion:268}} {{champion:75}} {{champion:58}}), and spooky ghosts ({{champion:412}} {{champion:120}} {{champion:429}} {{champion:30}}) all beating the hell out of each other in a reasonably believable setting is cool.

Where else am I going to watch a hamster in a mech ({{champion:68}}) punch a disillusioned soldier with a magic sword ({{champion:92}})  in the face?

My roommate came at me with, "I know you're not super into fantasy games, but there's this pink-haired pyro who I think you'd enjoy playing."

Aaaand, then I played Annie almost exclusively to level 30, haha.
Funny you say that. When I got introduced to the game Smite by a friend he said "There's this cute little girl that turns into a tentacle monster." and then I played Scylla almost exclusively.

Sort of a mixed bag. I'd heard about it before as this big to do in the world of online games, but I never tried it out. A friend of mine tried it out because a friend of his tried it out, and then got me to try it out. It was pretty fun, but not amazing at first. I went home, installed the game and set up my own account. That's when I found the lore tabs, and suddenly the game turned into one of the most badass, hilarious, and emotional games I'd played. everything suddenly felt 10x more epic in game because I was like "this game has relevance to their whole universe!".

Basically, I heard about it before, a friend got me to try it, but the lore is what got me really hooked.

R.I.P. IoW, you will live on in our memories, just like DFG and FoN...
what items were low and fon??

IoW wasn't an item, it was a political establishment called the Institute of War, and is what made League of Legends a "League"

FoN was an item called the Force of Nature, it was basically a really really strong MR item that had Warmog's passive, Spirit Visage's passive, and a ton of MS built in.

I simply listed the IoW with DFG and FoN because those are things a lot of players miss that used to be a part of the game.

Oh. IoW abbreviations keeps messing with my head though. I keep looking at it as LoW but with a lowercase L. I remember when DFG was a thing on every match.

What season was Force of Nature? Season 2?
Pretty sure it got cut when they put in preseason 3, so they had it through season 2.
Ah. I thought so. Cause I joined in Season 3 and never saw it. So I figured it had to have been the season before.

This is similar to what happened to me.  I saw a friend playing it at school, though it looked fun, and downloaded it.  I think I read through all of the Journal of Justice issues on my second day of playing.  They were funny, interesting, and they made the game seem way more 'real' than a lot of other online games.  Sure, you were a really powerful 'hero'-type character like you are in most MMOs, but in the old lore that all made sense.  You were a Summoner.  You were strong, but you were not the 'only hope' for Runeterra.  You and your fellow Summoners worked to keep order through the Institute of War.  You commanded powerful 'Champions' to fight for you to solve political disputes.  Some of these Champions joined the League of Legends willingly (like Viktor, Sona, Caitlyn, Lulu, and Jax), while others were conscripted or forced into it (examples being Ezreal, Nocturne, Brand, Kayle, and Cho'Gath).  

As a Summoner, you were important.  You and your allies worked to keep the peace between the city-states.  You stopped the fighting in Kalamanda.  You ended the Noxian invasion of Ionia.  You kept dangerous creatures -whether from the Void, the Shadow Isles, or elsewhere- from bringing about destruction upon the world.  You worked behind the scenes to maintain order.  Whether or not others knew your name, you had an impact on things.  That concept seemed really cool to me when I started playing, and it still does.  I miss the old lore and I am slowly losing faith in Riot as time passes.  I don't think the ret-con needed to happen, but there's nothing I can do about that now.  The fact that we lost so much of what made the game interesting made me really ticked off for a while, but I had hopes Riot would replace what we lost with more content.  I am beginning to believe that will not happen.  

-------------------------------------------

That said, I do like the game.  It's a lot of fun and while I may not agree with everything the Balance Team does, they do a relatively good job of keeping all the Champions relatively balanced.  I also like the variety of the Champions overall.  There are over 120, so you're pretty much guaranteed to find one you like.  For example, I really like the concepts of transhumanism and the Technological Singularity, the point in the near future where humanity will have to evolve artificially in order to live to their fullest potential.  I wrote a few papers on it in high school and kept researching it in college.  When I saw Viktor I knew that I had found the perfect Champion for me.  I love his lore, his theme, his personality, and pretty much everything else about him.  

To this day I still consider Viktor my best Champion, and I have a lot of fun playing as him.  It's fun to sort of get in character when in the game, and his complex lore makes that really easy.  In all honesty, if he had come out now and had the very short 'few sentences' type of lore that new and ret-conned champions have been getting, I don't think I'd have as much fun, and probably wouldn't have stuck with him (and the game in general) as long as I have.  For example...  *"Viktor believes that humans are flawed and are inferior to machines.  He studied Techmaturgy in Zaun and came to the conclusion that in order for humanity to evolve and become perfect, they will need to relinquish their frail flesh bodies in favor of superior forms made of metal.  Through this "Glorious Evolution" mankind will forego the weaknesses of emotions and flesh and enter into a new age of wondrous techmaturgical advancement."*  I've tried to write in the style of the newer lore entries like Bard, Xerath, and Kalista.  It explains his basic theme, but it lacks a lot of the depth the original had.  If this was all that was available when I first joined the game, I don't think I would have stuck around for very long.  

-------------------------------------------

TL;DR:  I got into this game because of the lore, and I think a lot of what made this game interesting is being slowly leeched away.  I still have some faith in Riot, but this can only last so long.

I was actually contemptuous of League at first because I played Storm of the Imperial Sanctum on Starcraft and this game felt so much slower. Additionally, you couldn't deny minions and I'd have great fun playing a champ in SotIS and reaching level 5 while the enemies are still level 2 due to denies. (Yes, I was a DoTA-clone snob) They also had some items that I really liked (hello Khydarian Absorber and components), had STR/AGI/INT scaling, and some of the champions were shadow beings that wielded double scythe blades. (RIP Shadow.Geminus, you will be missed)

Then I suddenly got sick of SotIS after a few completely broken champions were released and the disconnect issues throwing games at the start (people can't reconnect to a Starcraft game for...reasons), so I switched to LoL and have been playing fairly consistently for years.

I heard a few friends talking about it for a couple weeks and finally decided to join in and find out what it was all about. They started "teaching" me how to play, (more of yelling at me to go do this or go buy this item over my shoulder.) It was fun at first but I grew annoyed of no one doing anything in my games. My friends talked as if they were so good, so I told them I would be better than them. Few months later I finally get to lvl 30 with them and my main at the time, WuKong, showed them what was up...(It was them...) Today I am the one teaching them.
